explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 3 since flash point 42.2 degC (closed-cup) (ICSC (2002)) is >=23 degC and <=60 degC.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 200 degC (Ullmanns (E) (6th, 2003)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 348 mg/kg bw for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 4.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 370 mg/kg bw for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on a LC50 value of 1900 mg/m3/2h (258.2 ppm/4h) for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 2. Since the LC50 value (1900 mg/m3/2h) was lower than 90% of saturated vapour pressure concentration (17,200 mg/m3), the classification criteria for gas was adopted.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on results of "corrosive" in tests with rabbits and guinea pigs (IUCLID (2000)) and information that its solution (5 g/L, 20 degC) has pH 12, the substance was classified into Category 1.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on results of "irritating" in more than one test with rabbits (IUCLID (2000)), information that its solution (5 g/L, 20 degC) has a pH 12, and the substance is corrosive to the skin, the substance was classified into Category 1.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. Although there are a report of "not sensitizing" in a guinea pig skin painting test (IUCLID (2000)), this test method is not approved by OECD and the details are not clear.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Although dose dependent chromosome aberration was reported in 4-month inhalation rat bone marrow chromosome aberration test (in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity tests) (IUCLID (2000)), this test is invalid since the experimental procedure and documentation do not meet current requirement (IUCLID (2000)). Classification was not possible due to lack of other data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. As relevant information, from in vitro mutagenicity tests, there is a report of a negative Ames test (IUCLID (2000)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system), Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system) May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It is reported that the symptoms produced in acute oral toxicity tests with rats, mice, rabbits and guinea pigs are similar: weakness, tremor, salivation, gasping, and convulsions (PATTY (5th, 2001)). The similar symptoms were reported following dermal or inhalation exposure to rats or mice except that inhalation caused respiratory irritation. The oral LD50 values in these species ranged from 320 mg/kg to 620 mg/kg, the dermal LD50 value is 370 mg/kg, and the inhalation LC50 values ranged from 0.78 mg/L/4h to 1.34 mg/L/4h. Since significant toxic effects are produced at dose levels within the guidance value range for Category 2 by oral and dermal routes, and Category 1 by the inhalation route, the substance was classified into Category 1 (central nervous system). In addition, since inhalation caused respiratory irritation and it is a corrosive substance, the substance was classified into Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Although it is reported that changes in cardiovascular system parameters and serum enzymes were observed at dose levels within the guidance value range for Category 2 in an inhalation test with rats and mice (IUCLID (2000)), this test was considered to be invalid since the experimental procedure and documentation did not meet current requirements (IUCLID (2000)). Therefore, classification was not possible due to lack of other test data.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 1 from its 96h-EC50 = 0.0885 mg/L for algae (Scenedesmus) (IUCLID, 2000).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 1 since its acute toxicity is Category 1 and it is not rapidly degradable (BIOWIN).
